comments.author: Clark Thomas

top_comment.text:
But why does the color STAY? That's what I don't get. The needle doesn't go 
far at all, and we're constantly shedding our skin with new skin. How does 
the ink stay in our bodies, in our cells?﻿
top_comment.author: Hypurman1

comments.text:
+Hypurman1 In the video series, Smarter Every Day explains that there are 
metals that make up the ink, basically the metals get deposited into the 
second layer of your skin. Your blood cells recognize them as foreign and 
carry the smaller fragments away, leading to fading of the tattoo. The 
larger fragments are too big to be flushed out by your cells, and they 
remain for years and years.
comments.author: somethingyouhave

comments.text:

strict rules on hoe to take care of it, then it won't fade away. Only 
people who dont take proper care of their tattoos or tattoo then it fades 
away.

comments.text:
It's not about what other people think of your tattoo; it's what you think 
of it. The reason behind your tattoo could be anything: it could be either 
because you like that specific piece of art, or either because it is a 
reminder of an important life event. It's the same as when you buy a 
certain piece of clothing. Why would you do that? You do it because you 
want to, because you like it, not because of what other people will think 
about it.

I understand that having too many tattoos might be a little bit shocking to 
those who don't have any, but no one should be there to judge. They have a 
reason to have that many. Respect that.
comments.author: Sandra Planelles

top_comment.text: The tattoo probably goes away when u are old old﻿

comments.text:
+Piper Bell It's all in the mind man! It's painful during the process but 
once we get through it and see that beautiful artwork on our skin, then it 
makes it all worth it and we come back for more, regardless of the pain and 
we're able to get through it. The first tattoo experience is the worst 
because it's mainly fear that brings us such tension but once we get use to 
it after the first one, then that fear either goes away or we're much more 
calm. At least we know what it feels like afterwards.
comments.author: Monica Marcum

comments.text:
+RevenTexX, Graphics Designer I wouldn't think so. They say if you get a 
tattoo on your inner forearm then it's pretty sensitive but in a spot like 
your upper arm near your shoulder than that's pretty bearable for most 
people. It all depends on your pain threshold and everyone has a different 
level of tolerance for pain BUT it also depends on the area as well. The 
upper arm tends to usually have more fat and the more fat you have on an 
area, the less it tends to hurt where else a bony area will hurt worse. To 
say the least, I think you'll be good. The feeling is not the most 
comfortable for some people but there are people that get tattoos and most 
are covered with them all over. If the pain was too much to bear than most 
people wouldn't do it. In fact, it can get pretty addicting. I wish you 
good luck!

i posted this over a month ago why are people still being  responding to 
it. i don't even check the replies.  I have tattoos, my boyfriend has

and are amazing pieces of artwork. our bodies are our own and when we're

comments.text: bullshit suck a cock with tattoos
comments.author: kibbeling boy

comments.text: I got that backwards: asterisk for bold, underscore for italics. *Sheesh*.
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
+Blackbird McKinsey

McKinsey:

For emphasis, you may *italicize* by setting off the text between 
asterisks; to *bold* your text, you may place an underscore character 
before and after.

I don't think I'm advocating negativity. I'm advocating that people with 
tattoos understand that many people who have a negative reaction to tattoos 
are responding to genetically determined universal indicators of health, 
fertility, and youth. Blame Darwin, if you must blame someone. Don't blame 
me, or socially constructed arbitrary standards of beauty. Employers and 
customers in business don't *care* if random tattooed person thinks 
decision makers *should* respond in an open minded way to tattoos. That's 
not negativity, it's reality.

All across the planet and down through the ages, clear skin, a feminine 
waist to hip ratio of .7, big arms and chest for men, clear eyes, long 
thick shiny hair, and lack of structural defects all signal genetic 
fitness, and generate a warm response in the viewer. Sure, there are 
cultural departures from that - Venus of Willendorf, tribal body 
modifications, etc., but these standards of natural unaltered 
attractiveness are much more uniform than they are diverse. Look at Hindu 
temple statues from a thousand years ago. They look like Playboy bunnies... 
but more voluptuous. If that's possible.

Here's the kicker: cultures don't agree on what looks like a good 
modification, but they all pretty much agree on what's naturally attractive 
(along with genetically determined local adaptations to the environment: 
East African women with large posteriors to store fat efficiently in a hot 
climate, etc.).
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
The expression that's something like "people with tattoos don't care if you 
don't have tattoos. people without tattoos care if you have tattoos" can 
have more than one meaning. I personally don't know anyone with visible 
tattoos, and that's probably because I'm in a conservative area and most 
people side-eye people who aren't too close to "base line" of what people 
are "supposed to" look like.  

I look a little "weird" in some people's eyes, but I study the standards of 
the culture and then make my choices what I'm willing to deal with that 
people will find "weird," and where it's more appropriate to just hang 
back. If someone notices my tattoos and says "I could never do that," and 
what they mean is "this isn't my thing," that's fine. If they look at my 
unoffensive images and latch onto the fact that it's a permanent image, I 
would need to leave the situation. That's how I interpret the saying.
comments.author: Blackbird McKinsey

comments.text:
"Blaming the negative reaction to tattoos on social conditioning is another 
example of that paradigm blindness." I'm not dismissing either influence. 
I'm trying to say that there are some things genetic, some things that are 
conditioning, and they are not always exclusive, and both should be 
pondered over. That's all. 

I don't call people narrow minded if they don't like tattoos. I call them 
narrow minded if they insist that everyone should think like them, or does 
think like them and isn't admitting it. 

"Who has the strength of will and intellectual independence to rebel in 
deed and not merely in appearance? And if they rebel in deed, do they care 
about appearance?" That's the assumption that the two are mutually 
exclusive. A high-minded "I don't care about appearance at all, it 
shouldn't matter at all" is just as bad as "if I look a certain way that's 
all that matters." And that's what I'm trying to say - there are categories 
in and of themselves, but it's not two completely separate things. Both 
have to be considered. What it SEEMS (caps because I'm not trying to use 
words you haven't, but explain how I'm reading) that you're saying that you 
can either have integrity and not have focus on what you look like, or you 
can be wrapped up in what you look like, and being that wrapped up is an 
indication of your poor choices and character.

I was going to say it's a scale, but it's not even that. Someone who is 
obsessed with makeup can be just as bad as someone with a cheap dragon 
tattoo winding around their neck and perching on their scalp. But one is 
more CULTURALLY acceptable than the other. (assume caps in this are 
italics, not yelling)

re: the man you referenced with the sunburst tattoo. That's exactly what I 
mean. I do agree, a lot of the time tattoos can be tacky, poor taste, and 
to fit in. But tasteful tattoos are on the rise, but people still insist 
that any and all tattoos are bad, on principle. I feel like we're actually 
pretty close to saying the same thing. But it seems that you're advocating 
negativity, and I'm trying to advocate positivity.

"they are failing to study what makes attractive people, attractive."

Or, they do not share the opinion that everyone should have the same beauty 
standards. "What makes attractive people" is different for different 
cultures, and can fluctuate based on a person's beliefs and background. 
This doesn't necessarily make one perception in that field better than the 
other. Some people would rather someone have long hair. Some would rather 
they have dark hair, some light. Some prefer people with tans, some prefer 
people pale (not connected to racism). Some people look at tattoos and go 
"that's attractive," other people go "NO. THAt'S NOT. HOW CAN YOU THINK SO 
WHEN IT'S OBVIOUSLY NOT." And that's what I'm trying to get at.

For an example - like I said before, I like a "classy" kind of style, so I 
have a tattoo of a teacup, which is somewhere I can choose to be visible or 
not. Judging by what I've read, (correct me if I'm wrong) you promote 
people having preconceptions about me, my judgement, and my character, 
based on the statement "I have a tattoo," because "the majority of people 
with tattoos are --" and without other factors. It would be wrong for an 
employer to ask me if I have any tattoos at all, and using that as a basis 
whether or not I'll be a good employee, without any other factors. 

People remove tattoos for a variety of reasons. Some of them are that they 
were impatient, didn't pay for good work or, like you said, they wanted to 
fit in. If a person can avoid these things, and still have a tattoo, they 
shouldn't be treated like they have those qualities anyway for the simple 
fact they put an image under their skin. Also, tattoo "removal" can be used 
to lighten poorly done tattoos, so a similar image can be used to cover it. 
Such as if someone had a cheap tattoo done at 18, but it didn't come out 
well. They might lighten it to 50%, then go to a better artist to put a 
similar, much better quality image over the top.

I think I may be running out of words to describe this? I agree, a lot of 
tattoos are badly done, in poor taste, and show character flaws of the 
person. But it's not because of the possession of a tattoo, it's because of 
variables. People should not be treated a certain way because they possess 
a tattoo, but what variables come into play.

If I say "there are ten people here, eight of them are tattooed." Certain 
groups of people will insist that means 8/10 people should not be hired, 
and are unprofessional and make poor choices. But then if you look deeper 
and find that 4/8 people have tattoos like the man you described - custom 
designed, well thought out, and for themselves even if it shows, there are 
people who would ignore that with a knee-jerk "BUT TATTOOS." That's what 
I'm trying to get at. 

"Being classy is my teenage rebellion." - R. McKinsey
comments.author: Blackbird McKinsey

comments.text:
Hmm.

My remark about gender roles was just another instance of   people failing 
to see the importance of inborn, genetically determined behaviors. Blaming 
the negative reaction to tattoos on social conditioning is another example 
of that paradigm blindness.

I can appreciate that it's hard to get your mind around the idea that there 
is an automatic, instinctual aversion on the part of some people against 
tattooing. It makes it impossible for you to blame other people and call 
them narrow minded when they don't like tattoos: “A man should look for 
what is, and not for what he thinks should be.”  
 -Einstein

"Prejudice against tattoos may not be because someone told you to think 
that way, but it may have something to do with someone telling you it was 
okay to think that way, so it took deeper root."

In my case, it's the other way around. I grew up bending over backward to 
give everyone and everything the benefit of the doubt, and resisting 
anyone's attempt to tell me to be suspicious. I had no right to my own 
opinion. I had no street sense and trusted everyone, believed everyone had 
a valid point of view.

Then I heard something that changed my life: "Some people have such an open 
mind, their brains fall out." I have become much more selective as I got 
older and more comfortable with my own desires and tastes, and willing to 
make certain judgments.

Who has the strength of will and intellectual independence to rebel in deed 
and not merely in appearance? And if they rebel in deed, do they care about 
appearance?


Someone criticised Lech Walensa (during the time he was defying the 
Kremlin) for appearing in public with his shirt collar buttoned, and no 
tie. George Will said "If Walensa is worried about anything around his 
neck, it's not a tie".

Thoreau said:
“Not till we are completely lost or turned around... do we begin to find 
ourselves.”  

For me, one of those moments of turning around came when I soloed an 
airplane for the first time. I had grown up being told that I was ugly, 
stupid, hopeless and would never do anything with my life, and above all, I 
did not have what it took to be an airplane pilot. I had to put myself in a 
position that was completely disorienting, and contrary to everything I 
thought I knew about myself, before I could sort out what was real from the 
social conditioning. It's an ongoing process for me.

It was transgressive. And I didn't have to get inked - that wasn't what I 
needed. Bono once told a crowd at a concert: "I'm a rock star. It's who I 
am, what I do. I was meant to do this. Probably not many of you listening 
to me are supposed to be rock stars. There is something that you are meant 
to do and be, though. The most important thing in lifer is to find that 
thing  and do it." I get the impression that a lot of people who get inked 
were actually supposed to do something else with that time, money, and 
effort and mental energy.


Thoreau: “Our life is frittered away by detail. Simplify, simplify.”   A 
tattoo is a complication of your visual presentation. Is the benefit of a 
tattoo worth the complication, both of the bearer's state of mind, as well 
as their impact on others? Evidently not in all cases, if you go on Youtube 
and look at all the people who are investigating ways to *remove them*.  I 
think it would be *very* interesting to interview all those people going to 
get tattoos removed; get to the bottom of the tattoo removal situation

I think that most people who get tattoos are following the herd; they're 
sure not expressing their individuality by getting tattoos like everyone 
else is doing. It's not transgressive and rebellious anymore. It can still 
be valid, but I see truly worthwhile tattoos all too rarely.

Frank Zappa said in his autobiography: "I insist on originality, always."

Thoreau said: “All good things are wild and free” and “be yourself- not 
your idea of what you think somebody else's idea of yourself should be.”   
So that's why I still think that the yellow sunburst tattoo I saw on that 
guy 40 years ago is still cool.  I think he was himself, wild and free. He 
was a professional who (transgressing against social norms of the time) got 
a tattoo he designed himself that was deeply meaningful. And he was unique.



I think my comment last night missed the point in one aspect: people who 
have  unattractive elements in their presentation are not failing to look 
in the mirror; they are failing to study what makes attractive people, 
attractive. They are spending their lives in an echo chamber of their peers 
who are reinforcing their unrealistic ideas of what looks good to most 
people. Either that, or (as was true in my case before I improved my dress, 
shaved off my ugly beard, cut my hair, gained weight and fixed my skin) 
they don't know that it is possible to improve one's appearance, or how 
important it is to do so (to the extent possible).



“The significant problems we have cannot be solved at the same level of 
thinking with which we created them.”  
-Einstein

In the case of deciding what is the best next move for a young person, that 
requires something truly transgressive: rebelling against one's peer group, 
not against one's parents or 'society'. “I have forced myself to contradict 
myself in order to avoid conforming to my own taste.”
― Marcel Duchamp



“The formulation of the problem is often more essential than its solution, 
which may be merely a matter of mathematical or experimental skill.”   
 -Einstein
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
" Many people perceive tattoos  subconsciously as a deliberately self 
inflicted defect. Don't get me started on face piercings." Regarding that, 
I think more of my point was just proven by that sentence. People are used 
to ear piercings on women. Though it's still a piercing, still a "self 
inflicted defect." It's not cut-and-dried, but it still has to do with what 
people are used to, still somewhat having to do with what they're told they 
should get used to, told what's acceptable.

"Why do you think furnishings for babies' rooms are full of pictures of 
fluffy baby bunnies and baby ducks? Why do you think childrens blankets 
don't have morbid scary pictures of ugly witches and demons and so on?" I 
know a family who decorates in sort of "Harley Davidson" and skulls motifs. 
Even with their small children (though I think one of their children hs a 
skull shirt with a pink bow on it, but similar themes). I am not convinced 
that babies are "hard wired" to like pastels and "fluffy bunnies." There 
are actually evidences that small children and infants prefer brighter 
colors because they're more visually interesting (I'm not saying you 
mentioned pastels, but going with the concept). So the parents dress babies 
in "cute" things, when the babies don't care. And then the parents say it's 
what's acceptable for babies, when it's really what's attractive for the 
parents to be using. Not in EVERY case, however, but the point is that it's 
not the rule. Humans are not the same as sparrows. I know of children 
who've loved red-eyed rats and Beetlejuice from a young age.

I'm not trying to debate things like gender differences. What I'm trying to 
say is that you're completely discounting any influence of conditioning. 
I'm trying to say that I don't completely disagree, but conditioning has to 
be acknowledged. Like people were conditioned to think that women in 
trousers was vulgar. Or that women wearing makeup was vulgar. Or that 
because the culture you find yourself in says dress boys in blue because 
they like it, that's ridiculous. If he grows up some and chooses that, 
okay, but conditioning has to be acknowledged to play some part. Not in an 
effort to dismiss every opinion and belief and what other people say is 
right or wrong, but it's trying to work the equation while leaving out a 
part that doesn't quite fit with preconception that "people don't like 
tattoos because human instinct knows they're negative." 

Prejudice against tattoos may not be because someone told you to think that 
way, but it may have something to do with someone telling you it was okay 
to think that way, so it took deeper root. If you ponder over it and don't 
think that's the case, then okay, but the fact is, it's worth pondering 
over instead of jumping past it because it's uncomfortable to question.

There are things in this (USA) culture that are generally acceptable, 
generally unacceptable, and everywhere in-between. And then if you go 
somewhere else, there is a different scale. It doesn't necessarily make one 
culture better or worse, but the differences should have us looking again 
at what we consider hard-and-fast rules. It's never good to just bulldoze 
through society with "I CAN LOOK LIKE WHAT I WANT DON'T TELL ME ANYTHING," 
but it's also wrong to say, for example, tattoos are always bad, this 
haircut is always bad, mature people always dress a certain way, everyone 
should have the same standard of beauty.
comments.author: Blackbird McKinsey

comments.text:
Ah. I didn't use the word 'dirty' first in this conversation. Someone else 
did. I only used it to say I *wasn't* calling tattoos dirty when I referred 
to un-inked skin as 'clean'. Clean meaning un-inked. Someone else ran with 
the dirty meme.

However, that is really the point, though,  after all.

People have an automatic negative response to tattoos because even though 
tattoos might not be unclean in the sanitary sense of the word, they are 
perceived negatively because they subconsciously remind people of dirt or 
defects.

I know it's really hard for a tattooed person to hear, but you are 
mistaken: the reason people perceive tattoos negatively is not because 
society has influenced their ideas of beauty, it's because of a hardwired 
aversion to anything on or in the body that looks like any kind of defect. 
Many people perceive tattoos  subconsciously as a deliberately self 
inflicted defect. Don't get me started on face piercings.

Cognitive scientists/ethologists did an experiment years ago where they 
waved a black silhouette of a bird of prey over a nest full of newly 
hatched sparrows which had never seen a real hawk. The baby birds freaked 
out. Why? because it is possible for any organism to have a genetically 
determined, innate, negative reaction to certain sights. Why do you think 
furnishings for babies' rooms are full of pictures of fluffy baby bunnies 
and baby ducks? Why do you think childrens blankets don't have morbid scary 
pictures of ugly witches and demons and so on? I had curtains over my crib 
that had random spiky geometric shapes on them, and the pattern looked 
scary to me. That's maybe my earliest memory.

I remember years ago I grew a beard and a guy at work kept telling me it 
looked dirty. He said all beards looked dirty. He said Willie Nelson looked 
dirty.

it relates to a personal aesthetic, and those values are innate. It's not 
really a thought, it's an emotional reaction like you would have if you saw 
a rabbit get hit by a car. No body told me that's hard to look at - I feel 
it. Same with tattoos.

You never see it anymore, but there used to be a trend to install a lot of 
ornamental doodads on your car from the JC Whitney catalog. People who did 
that were generally ridiculed. Why? Because adding unnecessary stuff to 
something that is already complete confuses the impression the pure design 
is supposed to create.

Here's an analogy: some people claim that boys and girl babies should be 
raised the same, that gender differences are purely a social construct. 
However, there are huge differences that are obviously innate if a person 
is open minded enough to see them. For example, boys play much rougher than 
girls, who are way more social in their activities. Try reading a book 
called *The Red Queen*. It's full of evidence that gender differences are  
innate. The prejudice I have against tattoos is not because somebody told 
me to think that way: it's because they generally give me the creeps.

There are some exceptions, but that's just the way it is. I know you 
believe that somebody convinced me that tattoos look unattractive; it never 
happened.  I have a negative reaction in my body/gut/intuition, not in my 
'thinking/reasoning' brain. It's automatic, nobody ever talked me into it. 
Nowadays when I see someone who has failed to maximize their 
attractiveness, it really hits me. Overweight, poor grooming, tasteless 
color combinations or ill fitting clothes, expensive impractical ornate 
fingernails, smoking, on and on, I just think, 'gah'. Is there no one to 
tell that person to look in a mirror?

I think it's a trend to take the easy way out, dress up the outside.

A think an awesome body modification for  everyone is to stop eating empty 
carbs, get down to their ideal weight and then start lifting weights. To 
me, no matter who the person is, male, female, any age, that is 100 times 
more attractive than tats or face/body piercings, which put me right off.
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
That makes more sense. However, I based what I said off what YOU originally 
said, which was in the most part generalizations and phrasing like "tattoos 
are" instead of "tattoos can be in these situations."

I know you knew what you meant, and I understand that, but I was replying 
to what I read, please understand that.

I don't think it's worth trying to convince you why I think it's wrong to 
hold all tattoos unprofessional. But I do disagree - people are taught by 
people who insist it's unprofessional, and then people with the 
decision-making power cite the people who are taught tattoos are 
unprofessional, by the people with the decision making power. It's not 
something that should just be recklessly ignored, but I do think something 
has to be said about the cycle. 

When you use the word "dirty," however, there are people who would know you 
mean "not blank," then there are people who hear the word and it goes into 
their bank of "ew, tattoos" and they add "but they're dirty" to the 
arsenal, along with the wrong kind of discrimination.

So I suppose I can see and agree with some of your points, but I don't see 
it as a reason to discriminate against all tattoos whatsoever, whether in a 
professional capacity or not. I pride myself on having what you might call 
a "classy" streak (it's just a style I like, not trying to say anything 
arrogant), so I do know that tattoos can go really, really badly and yes, 
contribute to unprofessional image. But in my attempt to be discriminating 
in a positive way (trying to make good choices, not just prejudiced, which 
is how people tend to use the word) I have come across a vein of tattooing 
that I do consider classy and professional. And that's the style that I've 
chosen to get.

I think that's what I mean - I understand. But I also want to spread the 
awareness that just because something is called "Tattoo" it doesn't speak 
to the style, quality, placement, image, or reasoning. That has to be 
judged on its own, without the knee-jerk reaction.

Such as if someone described their appearance as "gothic" to me in text, 
that means almost nothing. There's bad gothic for a certain job, then 
there's inconsequential gothic for a certain job, but if I turn them away 
because of a certain word I won't look further into, the problem is with me 
just as much as if they showed up with blue liberty spikes expecting to 
land an office job.
comments.author: Blackbird McKinsey

comments.text:
+Blackbird McKinsey
Hello Blackbird:

Hope you don't think *I* am rude, vile and narrow minded. I am trying to be 
civil while expressing an opinion about what I perceive to be a common 
mistake in our culture. I am trying to be if not high minded, at least not 
base or vile. I hope I am open minded enough to appreciate *some*  ink, and 
not be negative about everyone who ever had a tattoo.

When I said uninked skin was 'clean', that's not as opposed to 'dirty', 
it's as opposed to 'inked'. I wasn't saying tattoos are 'dirty'.

And no, it's not an automatic poor choice - but I was thinking of a guy who 
interviewed with me for a public contact job who had some kind of writhing 
vine/animal/flaming thing crawling out of his shirt and up around his neck 
onto his head. He looked contagious, or infested. Not a really 
confidence-inspiring look.

When I was 14, in 1972, I met a guy who had a tattoo of a rising sun sort 
of starburst on his wrist. Yellow, the color of equality in Buddhism. It 
had 13 rays, and the rays were square ended, and the ink went more than 
half  the way around his wrist - so no matter what position he had his arm, 
he could always see at least part of the image.

there was more to it, but I have forgotten it. It was a random five minute 
conversation 40 years ago.  He had a really good explanation for his 
decision.

Tattoos then were relatively rare - certainly among the professional class, 
of which he was a member. That's why it stuck in my mind. He was a real 
individual- so much, in fact, that he was wary of explaining the meaning of 
the design to me because he didn't want anyone to possibly copy it.

that's my formative years tattoo experience.

And it has something to do with my rolling my eyes when I meet someone who 
wants to be seen as a special unique snowflake when they picked a butterfly 
out of a catalog and had to have a couple shots of tequila to go through 
with it. It just looks like a failure of imagination, which leaves me 
depressed.

. When you say "some ARE badly done and unprofessional, the well done ones 
are lumped into the same category" - well, that's just normal human nature. 
If someone says something annoying  to you that you have heard from many 
other people before, do you personally treat the annoying person as an 
individual? Or do you think: "gah, not again"?

You also say " because people are told they must hide any and all tattoos, 
it perpetuates the idea that all tattoos are unprofessional."

I think you have it backward. Because tattoos are unprofessional, they are 
to be kept hidden in any well run business. Why are they unprofessional? 
because a significant percentage of the population thinks *just like me*: 
many or most tattoos look bad, and send a negative message about the 
bearer's judgment. The gut level, instantaneous, genetically modulated 
 negative reaction to tattoos on the part of a significant percentage of 
the general population causes most reasonable responsible managers (modesty 
forbids, but) to ask they are kept covered.

I hope that's not vile, etc.

I just had to respond because it really got me thinking and I wanted to get 
to the bottom of what was bugging me about the current state of affairs.

Thank you for sharing.
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
+Ozle Bozle
Thank you for your thoughtful reply.

The "I can't stand it" was a reference to someone with lots of tasteless 
visible tats. That's because I seldom see anyone fully tatted that looks 
good. I guess an exception would be someone with Maori or Hawaiian style - 
looking. I don't know what you call it, tribal maybe? I am not up on the 
terminology. I think it's because that look  is associated with what I 
would call a 'classical' look: influenced by a preliterate and maybe less 
contrived, neurotic and self conscious sensibility. I think I am rebelling 
against modern life in some ways. It's just tragic when I see someone with 
some transient, shallow pop culture icon on their skin, the same as 10 
other people who went to the shop the year that image was popular.

That's the same human body  that inspired the great art of the ages, and it 
was enough without tattoos, generally. I mean, think of Michelangelo's 
*David*. Now think of it with tattoos. In fact, I expect to see a photoshop 
of that someday - now that I am tossing the meme out there, I am sure 
someone will run with it, if not already.

It's the same reason I hate seeing people wearing conspicuous logos on hats 
and shirts - I ask them if they have a sponsorship deal worked out. I think 
it looks like a person doesn't value themselves and their uniqueness 
enough, and so they think that something that's only skin deep will have 
value or bring value or show value.

It could - 40 years ago before tats got big I always looked at them with 
interest and  approval if they meant something.


40 years ago if someone had a well thought out,  original design tattoo, it 
really had an impact. Now so many  are  derivative and unoriginal... the 
impact is diluted.

I stand by my prediction that young people in the future will rebel against 
body modification.

Gosh I sound like a crusty old man.
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
+FightClub MeetsHere That's part of the spread of misinformation that 
tattoos are dirty. They're not, but people have reactions to them and go 
"ew" because people who don't like them and don't listen to people 
explaining them infect others with the "but they're dirty" mentality, which 
is baseless.

Loads of visible tattoos aren't a good idea, no. But still, it depends on 
the person. If someone's trying to get a certain job and has something 
tattooed onto their forehead, yeah, that's poor judgement. 

You can say "unless it's well done and rare" but the thing is, that's two 
reasons that people are against tattoos. People insist that they know more 
about the experience and process, that it's "dirty" than the person who 
actually has the tattoo, went into the shop to get it. Because some ARE 
badly done and unprofessional, the well done ones are lumped into the same 
category. Also, because people are told they must hide any and all tattoos, 
it perpetuates the idea that all tattoos are unprofessional. Whereas yes, 
there's a difference between a pin-up tattoo in a visible place vs. 
something more low-key and a classier image that only shows when you roll 
your sleeves up.

Don't get me wrong - yeah, there are a lot of bad tattoos and a lot of bad 
attitude and culture that goes with SOME aspects. But to use a real 
example, yes I like tattoos. But, like you said, ones that are well done 
and with discretion in placement. I have tattoos. I walked into a clean and 
classy shop. I was respected by the staff and artists. I picked some images 
that I'm pretty sure people have to work really hard to be offended over. 
Finished, left, healed. It's under my sleeve, so I can choose whether or 
not it shows.

There are people who still think all tattoos are disgusting and they get to 
insult people for having a tattoo of a clean and crisp star on their wrist, 
which they got in a decent shop after sitting on the idea for six months. 
And it's wrong. People can have opinions, yes. But that does not exempt 
them from being called out on making things up to justify being rude and 
vile and narrow-minded. 

If my doctor had skull and crossbones on the back of their hands, I'd raise 
my eyebrows. If I saw them in a shop with a tank top on, and they had their 
shoulders tattooed with flowers or books, I wouldn't care. And no one else 
should, because it's not "dirty," it's not an automatic "poor choice," it's 
something that someone decided was beautiful and they wanted to spend money 
on.
comments.author: Blackbird McKinsey

comments.text:
+FightClub MeetsHere I only have three tattoos, but I sometimes feel a 
little taken aback when I realize somebody has no tattoos because I'm so 
used to seeing mine on my skin so blank skin is a surprise lol. I 
understand that not everybody likes them, not everybody has to, but just 
because somebody has no tattoos doesn't mean they have "better judgement" 
over somebody who does. People who get tattoos get them because they want a 
piece of art on their body. It's not bad judgement. It's completely fine 
saying that you don't like them, but it is a little childish to act so 
repulsed by them and say you "can't stand the sight," in my opinion.
comments.author: Ozle Bozle

comments.text: +FightClub MeetsHere  I have never met an adult who regrets their tatts ;)
comments.author: Kinuoxx

comments.text:
The difference in perspective is because looking at a normal person is a 
normal experience. People with tattoos don't (as a general rule)  have a 
negative reaction to a clean skin.

People with no tattoos are tattoo-less because they have a gut level 
negative reaction to the sight. It's like graffiti, a rusty car, or a messy 
junky house that needs painting and a lawncut. Unless it's really well done *and 
rare* we get tired of it.

I would not hire a person with lots of visible tattoos, because I can't 
stand the sight. It is a constant reminder that this person has *bad 
judgment*: deliberately making themselves unattractive to a large swath of 
the population, for no tangible value.

 In 20 years teenagers will be rebelling against tattooing, and coming up 
with high minded rationalizations for their aversion.
comments.author: FightClub MeetsHere

comments.text:
+NZpnw My grandfather served in the army, and was tatted all the way up his 
arms and all over his back and chest. He was around 70 when he died and 
CONSTANTLY got asked if he regrets his tattoos before that. His answer was 
always along the lines of "FUCK no! Tattoos are art, and each one of these 
is a memory! Are you asking me if I regret my life, my choices and all the 
good memories in it??" He then would point to the tattoos of Grandma's 
name, my mom and uncles names, and mine and my sibling's names. "Are you 
asking me if I regret my wife, my sons and daughter and my grand babies? 
Why would I regret immortalizing their names where I can easily brag about 
my beautiful family??"


Long story short, every old person I've met doesn't regret their tattoos.

comments.text:
+Vanimic I hate pain, but I have three (shoulderblade, collarbone, and 
stomach).(collarbone hurt like a bitch i wanted to die damn it xD) But I 
dont regret any of them. I was pretty happy after that. It is sore for a 
couple of days, but it is well bearable.
comments.author: Vanimic

comments.text:
Painful? Yes. If it wasn't painful, nothing would stop people from having 
one. You have to EARN it.

If You can get AIDS or hepatite ? Hell no. You can get infection, but its 
only if you treat your tattoo like crap when it's healing. 98 percent of 
tattoo r healing perfectly.
comments.author: Vanimic

captions.text: Hey it's me Destin
welcome back to Smarter Every Day.
Not really sure how this is gonna work out
but I want to know a little bit more about tattoos.
So I'm just walking up to a tattoo parlour
and seeing if they will let me video a tattoo
being applied in slow motion with a Phantom.
Let's see how this works.
[tattoo machine buzz]
OK we're in the shop,
this is.. Leah? Right?
- Mm hmm. Hi.
- OK this is Leah and she's an artist.
We're not supposed to say..
What, is that what we call you?
- A tattoo artist, tattooer, tattooist,
in England they use tattooist.
- Excellent. OK so, can you teach us how to
tattoo somebody with.. I guess this is the gun right?
- Well machine, we don't call it a gun,
that's a no no.
- So what do we have here?
- This is a rotary machine.
There are a few different types of tattoo machines
but the most commonly used is the coil
and I would say the second most common
is the rotary machine.
- Oh really. Can you show us how it works?
- Sure. This itself is the motor.
- Ahuh.
- The head of the needle, actually the needle bar
connects here, and it goes through a tube,
which this is.
- Is that what you hold?
- We hold this. This is technically the grip.
I'm gonna put on gloves.
Not because I really need to in this case
because I'm not tattooing anyone
and all of this is sterile, but it's habit.
It feels strange to open a bag without gloves on.
- Oh really?
- So I'm just gonna do it.
- So it's kind of an important thing?
- Yeah.
(Destin) I used to think that a tattoo machine came to a single
needle point and it injected ink under the skin.
It's actually multiple needles and they're grouped
together for lining, however for shading it's
more like a paintbrush. Ink is held in between
those multiple needle points using capillary action
and when it punctures the skin it drags the ink
down into the dermis.
- Tada!
- Gotcha. So you've got.. Now you have a needle
in a tube attached to a machine, and you're
ready to make that machine work.
So what do you do? Power I'm guessing?
- Power.
- Rotary machines are pretty easy to understand.
Here this motor has rotational motion, and it's
translated to linear motion here at the needle bar.
That's pretty simple right?
Coil machines however are a bit more complicated.
When Leah steps on this foot pedal, that direct
current is applied to the two coils.
This turns those coils into an electromagnet
and it pulls this armature bar down,
moving the needle. When the armature bar
moves down, it breaks the circuit away from the
contact screw and that causes the electromagnetic
field to collapse. The spring then returns the
armature and it reenergizes the circuit.
This just happens over and over again
and that's it. That's how a coil machine works.
One word of caution though.
Just because you understand how a coil
machine works, doesn't mean you know how
to use it.
Did you really tattoo yourself?
You did it? Let me see.
- Yeah it's ridiculous.
- Oh that's..
- That's what happens.
- So it's a bad idea?
- It's a very bad idea.
- What's your name?
- Shawn.
- Shawn says do not tattoo yourself.
Go to a professional like Leah right.
- Yes.
(Destin) OK now that we know how the machines work
it's time to investigate what the needles
are doing to the skin.
I brought special lights and a special macro lens
so we can record it at first 1500 frames per second
and then ramp it up to 3200 frames per second.
This is why tattoos hurt.
[music]
OK I have decided that I want to feel what this
needle feels like because it's actually going
in the skin and pulling it up and you said you can
do this without actually tattooing me.
- Yeah I'm not gonna use..
I'm just gonna use a needle.
- I'm a little nervous.
I want to know what it feels like,
but I don't want a tattoo.
This is the next best thing right?
- Yeah exactly.
- OK, deep breath in.
- Deep breath in, breathe it out slowly.
[tattoo machine buzz]
- Whewhoo. That wasn't bad.
- OK.
- OK I can handle that.
- That was it.
- OK what did you do?
- See there?
- Oh. I can see why people get addicted to that.
Because it's like a.. it's like fear.
- Yeah.
- So this was the line needle and this was
the shading needle.
- Correct.
- And how many needles were on the line needle?
- Five.
- And how many were on the shading needle?
- Seven.
- There you go. Smarter Every Day.
- On the front of your forearm I think it hurts more than the back.
- You think I could take it?
- Of course you could.
- Alright, so I hope you enjoyed this episode of
Smarter Every Day. If you want to continue getting
smarter by letting me do crazy stuff, please
support Smarter Every Day on audible.com.  (UNLESS YOU'RE DEAF.  That wouldn't make sense)
So go to audible.com/smarter and you can (IF YOU'RE DEAF and you want to support SED, Patreon probably makes more sense)
download any audio book you want for free. (That link is at Patreon.com/SmarterEveryDay)
I have learned that Leah actually reads a lot.
Do you have a book that you recommend?
- Yes I'd recommend Native Son by
Richard Wright.
- Yeah?
- Mm hmm.
- OK just.. just continue.
- OK
- Anyway, so uh.. Anyway, audible.com/smarter
that helps Smarter Every Day and it's probably
gonna pay for Leah's work here.
So, also, follow Leah and Seejay.
I'll leave links in the video description.
She has a really cool Instagram account.
- You see what I mean about the frosting right?
(Destin) I do.
- How it elevates the top layer of skin there.
- OK, so when you..
- Are we getting Smarter Every Day?
- Yeah.
Do you actually know about Smarter Every Day?
- Yeah I subscribe to it.
- Oh fantastic. Was this done here?
- It was. Leah did it.
- Awesome. Crazy.
Did I just get cred because that guy knew who I was?
- Yes.
- OK excellent. [laugh]
- You're not just some weirdo coming into my shop.
[laughs]
(Destin) Alright so this is your famous tattoo?
- I posted on reddit and got a few hits.
- That's awesome.
Do you like macaroni and cheese?
- Yes.
- Anyway, I'm Destin.
You're getting Smarter Every Day.
Have a good one.
This is fake by the way.
We're not actually tattooing me. [laugh]
It was a good fake though.

title: TATTOOING Close Up (in Slow Motion) - Smarter Every Day 122
